subject: Sleep
title: Sleeping Together in the Middle Ages
description: A quick, practical guide to Sleeping Together in the Middle Ages.

hook.text: In medieval Europe, entire families slept in one bed. Strangers at an inn shared a bed without question.

buildup.text: Private beds and bedrooms didn't exist for ordinary people. Beds were the most expensive furniture item owned.

discovery.text: Communal sleeping provided warmth in unheated homes and was not considered unusual or intimate.

twist.text: Kings displayed their beds publicly as symbols of wealth. The great bed of Ware was built to hold 15 people.

climax.text: Private sleeping is a modern luxury. For most of history, sleep was a communal activity.

punchline.text: Sleeping alone is historically stranger than sleeping with strangers.

quiz.question: Why was communal sleeping normal in medieval Europe?
options: People were afraid of the dark
Beds were expensive and body heat provided warmth
